intro: Phalangium eccremorrhizum, commonly known as the ghost plant, is a unique member of the family Pichiaceae. It is a non-photosynthetic plant that relies entirely on its host for nutrients, forming a symbiotic relationship with certain fungi. The plant lacks true roots, leaves, and stems, instead consisting of a cluster of filaments that grow from the base of the host. It is often found in moist, shaded environments, typically associated with mosses or other fungi. Its distinctive appearance and ecological role make it an intriguing subject in botanical studies.
